pr_title: GEODE-7670: Add Tests for PR clear

timeline.message: GEODE-7670: Fixed and added tests
GEODE-7670: Fixed and added tests
GEODE-7670: Fixed and added tests

timeline.bodyText: can you add more shortcuts?
timeline.author: gesterzhou

replies.bodyText: There are other tickets aimed at testing concurrent operations with overflow, persistence, etc. Adding more region types should be done as part of the other tickets (that's why I set the RegionShortcut to be configurable through parameters), not this one.
replies.author: jujoramos

timeline.bodyText: after the first clear, all other gets() will not really do anything. You should re-populateRegion again before next clear.
timeline.author: gesterzhou

replies.bodyText: The test is still valid, though, we aim to verify that there are no issues with concurrent gets and concurrent clears, doesn't matter how many entries (if any) the region has. There is another method within the class that tests concurrent gets + puts + clears.
replies.author: jujoramos

timeline.bodyText: you need to measure how long a clear() took. If it's more than 5 seconds, something must be wrong.
timeline.author: gesterzhou

replies.bodyText: I'm not following you on this one... why only 5 seconds?, and why should the test verify how long the operation actually took?. The method basically executes the clear operation for a specific period of time to be able to interleave this operation with other concurrent ones in the cache. Measuring how long the operation took should be part of another ticket (a performance one, probably).
replies.author: jujoramos

replies.bodyText: 5 seconds is rvv domination timeout. If clear operation took more than 5 seconds, something must be wrong. No need to measure other operations' time.
replies.author: gesterzhou

replies.bodyText: @gesterzhou : I still don't understand what these tests have to do with the fact that a clear operation should take less than 5 seconds. The ticket is to purely verify that clear can be executed while other cache operations are being executed at the same time on the same region, shouldn't we create an extra ticket to test the scenario you're talking about?.
replies.author: jujoramos

timeline.bodyText: it's better to change the continuous put into continuous putAll.
timeline.author: gesterzhou

replies.bodyText: Any reason for that?. I can certainly do it, just wondering what's the actual reasoning behind the request.
replies.author: jujoramos

replies.bodyText: putAll will have longer window to reproduce synchronization issues
replies.author: gesterzhou

replies.bodyText: Cool, will add another test to execute multiple putAll instead of regular put opertations.
replies.author: jujoramos

timeline.bodyText:
Shortening the test name :)
We have PRConcurrentMapOpsJUnitTest - similar to this?
timeline.author: agingade

replies.bodyText: This is a good start; other cache ops that can be added in mix are Region ops (destroyRegion, invalidateRegion), querying; Region with index, rebalance, etc.
replies.author: agingade

replies.bodyText:
I'm in favour of having clear names in tests and classes, that's why I prefer to use long ones :-). Regarding the second comment, strongly agreed!.
This PR is to specifically address GEODE-7670, that's why it only addresses gets and puts, we can certainly improve the test and add extra operations (or region types) as part of other tickets.
replies.author: jujoramos

replies.bodyText: @jujoramos name change and adding new ops I will leave it to you. The acceptance criteria and ticket heading doesn't match; anyways we could add additional tickets to try out other ops.
replies.author: agingade

timeline.bodyText: 2 secs may be long pauses...Since there is continuous cache operation, how about sleeping for few mili secs (say 50)
timeline.author: agingade

replies.bodyText: Changed.
replies.author: jujoramos

timeline.bodyText: 3 secs long sleep.
timeline.author: agingade

replies.bodyText: Changed.
replies.author: jujoramos

timeline.bodyText: This waits for message pertaining to region creation or status change. There is DistributionMessageObserver that can be used to see if any messages are still in progress.
timeline.author: agingade

replies.bodyText: Agreed, the DistributionMessageObserver can be used but it's a test hook and I've heard we want to get rid of that eventually, that's why I chose to use another approach (which seems to work fine, so I'm not sure I should to apply the requested change here).
replies.author: jujoramos

replies.bodyText: I won't foresee removal of observers; again there are multiple ways to do it; it is your choice :)
replies.author: agingade

timeline.bodyText:
This is going over the PRs entry/key set getting all the values. This will be consistent where-ever this is called.
Are we trying to see if the data in one vm is same as in another vm. Or are we trying to see data in primary buckets are same as in secondary buckets.
Fetching the local PR data-set and iterating over it will give the data stored in that vm.
Or just to see an op could be executed successfully after clear?
timeline.author: agingade

replies.author: jujoramos

replies.bodyText: What I am trying to says is, since you are iterating over the PR region; it will get the data from all the nodes. Thats remains same across all the nodes.
replies.author: agingade

replies.bodyText: @agingade : got your point, thanks for catching this. Will change the method to verify that the data both on the primary and secondary buckets are in sync.
replies.author: jujoramos

timeline.bodyText: No need to specify time; if someone changes the time and doesn't update it, this will become incorrect.
timeline.author: agingade

replies.bodyText: Done!.
replies.author: jujoramos

timeline.bodyText: Instead of CacheWriter, you can use DistributionMessageObserver. And can use VM.bounce* to kill vms. No need to wait for CacheWriter messaging implementation.
timeline.author: agingade

replies.bodyText: Same as above, I'm still inclined to use the CacheWriter for now instead of the DistributionMessageObserver hook. If the lifecycle of the listener changes, I'll be more than happy to use another approach :-). If you think this should block the PR from being merged, though, I'll explore using the DistributionMessageObserver.
replies.author: jujoramos

replies.bodyText: I don't think lifecycle of listeners changing. Its your choice.
replies.author: agingade

GEODE-7670: Add Tests for PR clear

Added distributed tests to verify that the clear operation on
Partitioned Regions works as expected when there are other
concurrent operations happening on the cache (puts, gets, members
added and members removed).

timeline.bodyText: This validation needs to be changed....The RVV's are maintained as local-rvv (local to the node/member) and array of remote-rvvs (all other members). The RVVs has to be taken for corresponding member from both dumps and compared.
timeline.author: agingade

timeline.message:
GEODE-7682: add PR.clear  API (#4755)

* GEODE-7683: introduce BR.cmnClearRegion

Co-authored-by: Xiaojian Zhou <gzhou@pivotal.io>

PR.clear's event id should be created and used in BR (#4805)

* GEODE-7857: PR.clear's event id should be created and used in BR

GEODE-7670: Add Tests for PR clear

Added distributed tests to verify that the clear operation on
Partitioned Regions works as expected when there are other
concurrent operations happening on the cache (put, putAll, get,
remove, removeAll, members added and members removed).

timeline.bodyText: The PartialClearException could happen here but not 100% will happen. Your assertion could fail here.
timeline.author: gesterzhou

replies.bodyText:
@gesterzhou
There are three members in this test: ACCESSOR, SERVER1 and SERVER2, both servers host primary buckets locally for the region. The clear operation is executed either from the ACCESSOR or SERVER1, and SERVER2 is always killed through the MemberKiller class (CacheWriter.beforeRegionClear()) before the clear is locally executed.
According to what I understand, the PartitionedRegionPartialClearException should always be thrown as SERVER2 doesn't get started (after the initial shutdown) until the clear "finishes", meaning that the clear coordinator will never be able to get the lock for all the primary buckets (the region is configured as PARTITION, not as PARTITION_REDUNDANT, so there are no secondary buckets that can become primary while SERVER2 is down).
Am I missing something here?, shouldn't the exception be thrown no matter what, given the above conditions?.

As a side note, the test clearOnNonRedundantPartitionRegionWithConcurrentPutGetRemoveShouldFailWhenNonCoordinatorMembersAreBounced failed 4 times out of 100 executions, the actual failure depends on whether the clear is executed on the ACCESSOR or SERVER1 vm.
The two failures seen when the clear is executed on the the ACCESSOR node are basically assertion errors, caused by the fact the the PartitionedRegionPartialClearException is not thrown (discussed above).
The two failures seen when the clear is executed on SERVER1, on the other hand, are caused by the fact that the exception message is different from the one expected by the test (I'll change this and update the PR).
replies.author: jujoramos
jujoramos

replies.bodyText:
Only when the primary holder cannot be found any where, the PartitionedRegionPartialClearException will be throw.
In your case, only killing server2. There're chances and races that the primary buckets are recreated quick enough on server1. So PartitionedRegionPartialClearException is not 100%.
replies.author: gesterzhou

replies.bodyText: Maybe I'm missing something here, but there's no activity on the cluster at the time server2 is killed, so the primaries previously hosted by that server shouldn't be recreated anywhere (and there are no secondaries to promote as the region is just PARTITION, not REDUNDANT_PARTITION). Moreover, and since server2 is abruptly shutdown, no other members can re-create the primaries as they don't have any of the data that was hosted by server2 at the time it was brought down.
replies.author: jujoramos

timeline.bodyText: It's recommended not to declare multiple variables inline, so this should ideally be split into three separate lines.
timeline.author: DonalEvans

timeline.bodyText: This warning suppression is not necessary, as the method is used in coordinatorsAndRegionTypes() below.
timeline.author: DonalEvans

timeline.bodyText: This warning suppression can be removed if the below line is changed to PartitionAttributes<String, String> attributes = new PartitionAttributesFactory<String, String>()
timeline.author: DonalEvans

timeline.bodyText: This warning suppression can be removed if the below line is changed to PartitionAttributes<String, String> attributes = new PartitionAttributesFactory<String, String>()
timeline.author: DonalEvans

timeline.bodyText: These warning suppressions can be safely removed if some changes are made in this method, as described below.
timeline.author: DonalEvans

timeline.bodyText: These can be changed to RegionVersionVector<?> to prevent "rawtypes" warnings.
timeline.author: DonalEvans
DonalEvans

timeline.bodyText: The arguments "start" and "finish" here might be better named as "startKey" and "endKey" or something similar, to make it clear that they are not related to time.
timeline.author: DonalEvans

timeline.bodyText: The arguments "start" and "finish" here might be better named as "startKey" and "endKey" or something similar, to make it clear that they are not related to time.
timeline.author: DonalEvans

timeline.bodyText: Instead of a while loop with a Thread.sleep(), it might be better to use the Timer and TimerTask classes to execute clears (specifically the scheduleAtFixedRate() method.) Entirely personal preference, but I do know that in general we try not to use Thread.sleep() directly in tests.
timeline.author: DonalEvans

timeline.message:
- Changes requested by reviewers.
- Standardized time unit used through the test.
